title: 110_hr4652
content:
The Act titled "Environmental Justice Access and Implementation Act of 2007" defines key terms. The Act titled "Environmental Justice Access and Implementation Act of 2007" defines environmental justice as fair treatment and meaningful involvement of all people regardless of race, color, national origin, educational level, or income in the development, implementation, and enforcement of environmental laws to ensure minority and low-income communities have access to public information and do not bear a disproportionate burden of pollution impacts. The Act defines environmental justice as fair treatment to prevent disproportionate health and environmental effects on minority and low-income communities. Criteria for identifying these communities include health vulnerabilities and exposure to environmental conditions. Exposure to environmental conditions includes facility density, proximity to hazardous sites, enforcement data, hazardous emissions, indoor and water quality, and traffic related to transport of polluting substances. Implementation and integration of federal environmental justice initiatives. The establishment of Offices of Environmental Justice is required for various government departments and agencies as per Executive Order 12898. This includes the Department of Defense, Department of Justice, Department of the Interior, Department of Agriculture, Department of Commerce, Department of Labor, Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Housing and Urban Development, Department of Transportation, Department of Energy, Department of Homeland Security, Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Management and Budget, Office of Science and Technology Policy, and Offices within the Executive Office of the President. The Offices of Environmental Justice must be established within various government departments and agencies, overseen by a Director of Senior Executive Service designation with environmental justice activities as their primary responsibility. These offices should integrate environmental justice strategies into agency operations and missions, addressing compliance with the Act. The Interagency Federal Working Group on Environmental Justice must coordinate training plans for Federal agencies, establish public participation goals, and survey agencies for compliance with the Act. The Interagency Federal Working Group on Environmental Justice is tasked with coordinating training plans, establishing public participation goals, and surveying agencies for compliance with the Act. Federal agencies are required to carry out outreach activities, respond to inquiries, and maintain websites and listservers. The Interagency Federal Working Group on Environmental Justice coordinates outreach activities, maintains websites, produces multimedia products, sponsors events, and provides content for education activities to stakeholders. They also fund outreach efforts managed outside the Federal Government. The Federal Government, in collaboration with stakeholders, aims to enhance partnerships and coordination for early input in environmental decision-making. $1,000,000 is authorized for each entity named in the section for fiscal years 2008 through 2018. For fiscal years 2008 through 2018, funds are authorized for sections 3(c), (d), and (e) as necessary. SEC. 4. COMMUNITY ACCESS AND PARTICIPATION IN FEDERAL ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE INITIATIVES. Community technology centers are established by federal agencies to provide technical assistance in environmental justice areas. These centers offer at least 10 hours of open access per week to help communities, especially those in low-income urban and rural areas, with environmental hazard issues. They can be located in places like libraries, community centers, and schools. Community technology centers are established in various locations like libraries, community centers, schools, churches, and low-income residential housing complexes to assist environmental justice communities. The President will recommend the minimum number of centers based on demographic profiles within 12 months of the Act's implementation. These centers help community members participate in cleanup and environmental development activities. The community technology centers assist environmental justice communities by providing technical assistance, reviewing documents, sponsoring workshops, informing community members about resources, offering training in facilitation and conflict resolution, and creating tailored technical assistance materials. The President and the Government Accountability Office are required to report on the implementation of the Act within specific timeframes. Authorization of Appropriations is granted to entities named in this section for fiscal years 2008 through 2018 to carry out the Act. SEC. 5. DOCUMENTATION AND REPORTS.

Annual reports on environmental justice in agencies identified in the Act will be presented to Congress by the President within 12 months of enactment. The Government Accountability Office will evaluate the Act's implementation and report to Congress within 18 months of enactment.
